SECRET.THE ARMY.HIGH COMMAND APPOINTMENTS.(See Minute 5.)THE PRIME MINISTER informed the War cabinet of certain changes proposed in Army appointments, after full consultation with the Secretary of State for War.General Sir John Dill, Chief of the ImperialGeneral Staff, would he retiring towards the end ofDecember, when he reached the age of 60. He had "been offered, and had accepted, the post of Governor of bombay. It was hoped that it would also he possiblefor him to be promoted Field Marshal in the near future.To succeed him as Chief of the Imperial GeneralStaff it was proposed to appoint General Sir Alan Brooke.General Brooke's successor as Commander-in-Chief, Home Forces, would be Lieut.-General Paget. -This would leave a vacancy in the command of the Army in South-East England, to which Major GeneralMontgomery would be appointed.The Prime Minister said that it was also proposed that Major-General Nye, at present Directorof Staff Duties, should he appointed as Vice-Chief ofthe Imperial General Staff, in succession to Sir HenryPownall, who would probably be appointed to beCommander-in-Chief in the Far East.The Prime Minister undertook to consider asuggestion that Lieut.-General Hutton, now Chief ofStaff to the Commander-in-Chief, India, should beappointed Commander-in-Chief in the Far East, and that sir Henry Pownall should be appointed in General Hutton'splace.The War cabinet took note, with approval, ofthese changes, which would be announced in the course of theweek, but would not take placeuntil about the end of the year.Great George Street, S.W. 1.
